articles.headline: A Spanish Bailout Would Test Europe’s Strained Finances
articles.snippet: Bailouts in Greece, Ireland and Portugal are manageable, but rescuing Spain’s larger economy could push Europe to the financial brink.
articles.abstract: Bailouts in Greece, Ireland and Portugal are manageable, but rescuing Spain’s larger economy could push Europe to the financial brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID  Europe so far has survived the bailout of Greece. The financial rescue of Ireland also is manageable. Even if Portugal becomes the third country to succumb and seek aid, as many people widely predict, it is unlikely to push Europe to the financial brink.

articles.headline: Squinkies Maker Savors Demand for Holiday’s Hot Toy
articles.snippet: A tiny company saw a need this year for affordable, collectible toys. It created a squishy toy, and now it can’t keep up with demand.
articles.abstract: A tiny company saw a need this year for affordable, collectible toys. It created a squishy toy, and now it can’t keep up with demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Midway through last year, as analysts tried to predict where the economy was going, the toy maker Bill Nichols decided he had the answer. He bet that the economy would still be so shaky this holiday season that a bargain-priced plastic toy would take off.

articles.headline: DeLay Is Convicted in Texas Donation Case
articles.snippet: A jury found Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, guilty in a case involving campaign donations.
articles.abstract: A jury found Tom DeLay, the former House majority leader, guilty in a case involving campaign donations.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.  Tom DeLay, one of the most powerful and divisive Republican lawmakers ever to come out of Texas, was convicted Wednesday of money-laundering charges in a state trial, five years after his indictment here forced him to resign as majority leader in the House of Representatives.

articles.headline: The Lessons of 10 Years of Talking Tech
articles.snippet: The tech column celebrates its 10th anniversary of reviewing hits like the BlackBerry and Kindle and misses like 3Com Audreye.
articles.abstract: The tech column celebrates its 10th anniversary of reviewing hits like the BlackBerry and Kindle and misses like 3Com Audreye.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s a special week in America. All over the country, families are gathering in warmly lighted homes. They’re sitting down to fancy feasts at decorated tables. They smile, they pour libations, they raise their glasses.

articles.headline: For Google, the Browser Does It All
articles.snippet: The company said it will introduce a lightweight netbook computer that runs Chrome by the end of the year.
articles.abstract: The company said it will introduce a lightweight netbook computer that runs Chrome by the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  When a Google engineer gave top executives computers running the company’s new Chrome operating system, Sergey Brin, Google’s co-founder, tried to hold on to his computer running an older version.

articles.headline: Netflix’s Move Onto the Web Stirs Rivalries
articles.snippet: Netflix has a strong grip on movie and television distribution — a grip Hollywood and cable TV want back.
articles.abstract: Netflix has a strong grip on movie and television distribution — a grip Hollywood and cable TV want back.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a matter of months, the movie delivery company Netflix has gone from being the fastest-growing first-class mail customer of the United States Postal Service to the biggest source of streaming Web traffic in North America during peak evening hours.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and David Carr

articles.headline: Sweet Potatoes Step Out From Under Marshmallows
articles.snippet: A Southern tradition has its incarnation as a fry to thank for its growing popularity.
articles.abstract: A Southern tradition has its incarnation as a fry to thank for its growing popularity.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  After generations of being smothered by a blanket of marshmallows on Thanksgiving and then forgotten for another 11 months, the irrepressible sweet potato is having its moment.

articles.headline: South Korea Reassesses Its Defenses After Attack
articles.snippet: President Lee Myung-bak announced changes as he accepted his defense minister’s resignation, but he has little maneuvering room in responding to North Korea.
articles.abstract: President Lee Myung-bak announced changes as he accepted his defense minister’s resignation, but he has little maneuvering room in responding to North Korea.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Responding to growing public criticism after a deadly North Korean attack, President Lee Myung-bak accepted the resignation of his defense minister on Thursday and announced changes in the military’s rules of engagement to make it easier for South Korea to strike back with greater force, especially if civilians are threatened.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and Mark McDonald
